description: From Middle English glade (“A gleam of light, bright space, an open space; an open or cleared space in a forest; a bright patch of sky; a bright surface of snow or ice”), also glode, glede, from Old English glæd (“shining, bright”), (compare Old Norse glaðr (“bright”)).

entries.meaning: An open passage through a wood; a grassy open or cleared space in a forest.
examples: […]  are creating more "glades," or cleared trails through the woods, for less experienced (blue) skiers. They're a throwback to the first days of skiing, before resorts cut wide swaths of trees, and machines rolled and packed the snow.

entries.meaning: An open space in the ice on a river or lake.
A bright surface of ice or snow.
(obsolete) A bright patch of sky; the bright space between clouds.
